metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Respondent (Ministerial Services Association representative)

facts.text: Consequent on the war, there was a phenomenal rise in the price of foodstuffs and of other essential commodities, and among the persons worst hit by it were the Government servants.
As a measure of relief to them, the Central and the Provincial Governments sanctioned a grant of grain allowances to them under various Resolutions passed in 1940.

The scheme adopted by the Central Government was that its employees stationed in various Provinces received the same benefit as the respective Provincial Government employees. But this scheme was found to be unsuitable for employees of the Central Government, as the allowances granted by the Provincial Governments were not uniform.

On 10th May, 1946, the Central Government appointed a Central Pay Commission to enquire into and report on the conditions of service of its employees with particular reference to the structure of their pay scales and standards of remuneration.
The Commission, presided over by Sir S. Varadachariar, recommended by its report dated 3rd May, 1947, the grant of dearness allowance on a specified scale.

On 27th May, 1947, the Government of Central Provinces and Berar appointed a Pay Committee to examine the recommendations of the Central Pay Commission and to report the extent to which and the modifications subject to which these recommendations should be accepted by the Provincial Government.

By its report dated 22nd June, 1948, the Committee recommended the grant of dearness allowance on a scale which, though practically identical with that adopted by the Commission in respect of salaries above Rs. 400 per mensem, was less than it as regards salaries of Rs. 400 per mensem or less.
These recommendations were accepted by the Government by its Resolution dated 16th September, 1948.

This difference in the result between the two scales naturally caused considerable dissatisfaction among the employees concerned, and after unsuccessful attempts to get redress on the executive side, they filed through their representative, the respondent, the present application under article 226 of the Constitution in Miscellaneous Petition No. 123 of 1953.

In the petition it was alleged that the State Government should have uniformly adopted the Government of India rates for all its servants and the discrimination in making the two-fold slab... is highly discriminatory.

The Government contested the petition on the grounds, firstly, that the claim for dearness allowance was not justiciable, and secondly, that the difference in the scales... did not violate article 14.

The learned Judges Sinha C.J. and Bhutt J. held that... the Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, was therefore bad. They accordingly issued a direction to the State Government that they do reconsider the question of dearness allowance payable to the employees concerned.
Appeal to Supreme Court by the State Government on a certificate granted under article 132(1) of the Constitution.

In paragraph 80 of the Report the Committee observed that while the Commission based its scale on the cost of living index, they themselves adopted the current level of prices as the basis for fixation of dearness allowance.
In paragraph 83... as they had revised the scale of basic pay, they were not including it in fixing the dearness allowance.
In paragraph 31, they observed that unlike the Commission they were taking into consideration the financial resources of the State in fixing the scale.
Mr. Nambiar also referred us to two Resolutions of the appellant dated 4th January, 1951, and 6th October, 1951, adopting the scale fixed by the Commission in respect of certain other categories.

legal_issues.text: Whether grant of dearness allowance is a matter ex gratia and not justiciable, such that no writ of mandamus or direction could be issued with reference thereto.
Whether the Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, fixing a scale of dearness allowance is repugnant to article 14 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Grant of dearness allowance is a matter ex gratia and not justiciable, and neither a writ of mandamus nor any direction could be issued with reference thereto.
The Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, is not hit by article 14 of the Constitution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; distinct entities of Union and States under Articles 12, 13(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: The assumption that the Committee had adopted the Report of the Commission in part and rejected it in part was itself without foundation, as the Committee approached the problem from a different angle.

respondent_arguments.text: The State Government servant has a right to be treated equally with the Central Government servant similarly situated; discrimination in adopting GOI rates above Rs.400 but lower below violates Article 14.

When once the Government passed a Resolution fixing a scale of allowance under Rule 44, that would be law as defined in article 13(3)(a) of the Constitution, and if that law infringed Article 14, it could be declared void.

court_reasoning.text: Under Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much. No right conferred on servants, no duty on State; mandamus misconceived.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dearness allowance is matter of grace, not right; distinguishable from arrears of salary as debt.

court_reasoning.text: The scheme in the Resolution grades DA according to pay slabs with progressive reduction; places all employees in same position within slab (except slight city adjustment); no discrimination within the scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in the Resolution itself brings it within prohibition of Article 14.

court_reasoning.text: Article 14 does not authorize striking down a law of one State on ground that in contrast with a law of another State (Centre) its provisions are discriminatory; sources of authority different.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot read Central Commission's report in conjunction with State Resolution; Union and States distinct entities.

court_reasoning.text: Committee approached problem differently: based on current prices not cost of living index; excluded pay element due to basic pay revision; considered State's financial resources.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Any similarity coincidental, not adoption in part.

holdings.text: The matters raised in the petition are not justiciable.
The Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, is not repugnant to Article 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Punjab Province v. Pandit Tara Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Held arrears of salary recoverable as debt; but dearness allowance claim not for arrears due under rules, but to compel grant at particular rate.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved Punjab case; salary not bounty, recoverable by action.
Petition of right does not lie for matters of grace, not right.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 14 equality; no discrimination between Centre and State actions; Resolution not 'law' violating fundamental rights in manner alleged.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Confers discretion on Government to grant compensatory allowances like DA; no right or duty enforceable by mandamus.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Arrears of salary attachable as debt; distinguished from DA claim.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order dated 10th September 1953 set aside; original petition under Article 226 held not justiciable and Resolution of 16th September 1948 upheld as not violating Article 14.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; direction to reconsider quashed.

key_quotes.text: "Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much. That being so, the prayer for mandamus is clearly misconceived."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on justiciability under Rule 44 FR.

key_quotes.text: "Article 14 does not authorise the striking down of a law of one State on the ground that in contrast with a law of another State on the same subject its provisions are discriminatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation limiting Article 14 to actions within same 'State' entity.

key_quotes.text: "It may no doubt sound hard that Government servants doing work of a similar kind... should receive different allowances but the rights of the parties have to be decided on legal considerations."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges equity concern but prioritizes legal limits.
